attributes.title: Effects of acupuncture for shoulder fracture: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q1.value: Effects of acupuncture for shoulder fracture: A systematic review and meta-analysis

q3.value:
is acupuncture effective for shoulder fracture?
Shoulder fractures, usually referred to proximal humeral fractures, are the third most prevalent fracture in the elderly population. The incidence increases with age and reaches a pick in mid-70s. Most of the fractures are from falls and osteoporosis and they hinder the activities of daily living.

q4.value: is acupuncture effective for shoulder fracture?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: Only RCTs will be included.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), PubMed, EMBASE and Web of Science will be searched. One Chinese database (CNKI) and eight Korean database (Korean Association of Medical Journal Editors, Korean National Assembly Digital Library, Oriental Medicine Advanced Searching Integrated System, Korean Association of Medical Journal Editors, Korean Studies Information Service System, National Digital Science Library, Database Periodical Information Academic and Korean Traditional Knowledge Portal) will be systematically searched from the inception to Jan 2020.

To find relevant literature unabled to be searched through searching engines, reference of found papers will be screened. The WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP) will be searched to investigate unpublished trials. We will contact to the researchers get the information about the ongoing study.

This review will include participants who have shoulder fracture without restriction of their age and sex. Onset is not considered for the inclusion criteria.

q13.value: RCTs extracted by search strategies will be included.

question.value: Pain scale will be the primary outcome.
standard mean differences and confidence intervals will be used.

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for preprint: PENERAPAN MODEL CREATIVE PROBLEM SOLVING BERBASIS KOMIK  STRIP DALAM PEMBELAJARAN FISIKA UNTUK MENINGKATKAN  KEMAMPUAN KOGNITIF SISWA

q1.value: PENERAPAN MODEL CREATIVE PROBLEM SOLVING BERBASIS KOMIK  STRIP DALAM PEMBELAJARAN FISIKA UNTUK MENINGKATKAN  KEMAMPUAN KOGNITIF SISWA

q3.value:
Tujuan  penulisan  ini  untuk  mendeskripsikan  penerapan  model  creative 
problem  solving  berbasis  komik  strip  dalam  pembelajaran  fisika  untuk  meningkatkan 
kemampuan  kognitif  siswa.  Penulisan  ini  dilatarbelakangi  oleh  masih  kurangnya 
pemahaman  siswa  terhadap  materi  pembelajaran  fisika.  Untuk  itu  perlu  ada  upaya  yang 
dapat  mengatasi  permasalahan  tersebut  dengan  menerapkan  model  creative  problem 
solving  berbasis komik strip. Model  creative problem solving    sebagai proses pemecahan 
masalah yang berbasis komik strip agar siswa menjadi termotivasi dan dapat meningkatkan 
hasil  belajarnya.  Metode  yang  digunakan  dalam  penulisan  ini  adalah  studi  kepustakaan 
dengan  mengkaji  beberapa  literatur  untuk  dianalisis  dan  dibuat  kesimpulan.  Hasil 
penulisan  ini  menunjukkan  bahwa  penerapan  model  creative  problem  solving  berbasis 
komik  strip  dalam  pembelajaran  fisika  dapat  menjadi  solusi  dari  permasalahan  yang 
ditemui dalam proses belajar mengajar di kelas. Model creative problem solving diterapkan 
dengan beberapa langkah antara lain: siswa melakukan klarifikasi berbagai masalah untuk 
dipecahkan,  setelah  masalah  dipilih  kemudian  diungkapkan  melalui  komik  strip, 
selanjutnya melakukan proses evaluasi dan seleksi untuk menemukan solusi dari masalah 
yang ditemukan. Dengan demikian, dapat meningkatkan kemampuan kognitif siswa

q4.value: Komik Strip, Creative Problem Solving, Kemampuan Kognitif

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

attributes.title: TAVRE: Impact of tactile augmentation in Virtual Reality exposure therapy for fear of heights

q1.value: TAVRE: Impact of tactile augmentation in Virtual Reality exposure therapy for fear of heights

q2.value: Ewelina Smoktunowicz, Philip Lindner, Per Carlbring

q3.value: Previous research suggests that Virtual Reality exposure for phobias can be augmented using synchronized tactile stimulation, yet results are inconclusive. This trial will evaluate whether any augmentation by tactile stimulation is moderated by task difficulty, and whether any difference in distress and habituation is mediated by difference in sense of presence.

q4.value:
H1. Time will have a negative effect on pulse (i.e., habituation).
H2. Time will have a negative effect on discomfort (i.e., habituation).
H3: Time will have a negative effect on fear of heights. 
H4. Tactile exposure (0=without, 1=with) will have positive main effect on pulse.
H5. Tactile exposure (0=without, 1=with) will have positive main effect on discomfort.
H6. Tactile exposure (0=without, 1=with) will have positive main effect on presence in virtual reality. 
H7. Level of task difficulty (0=easy, 1=hard) will have a positive main effect on pulse. 
H8. Level of task difficulty (0=easy, 1=hard) will have a positive main effect on discomfort. 
H9. Level of task difficulty (0=easy, 1=hard) will have a positive main effect on presence in virtual reality. 
H10. There will be a two-way interaction effect between tactile exposure and level of task difficulty on perceived discomfort: Under the condition of tactile exposure, perceived discomfort will be higher when task is difficult. 
H11. There will be a two-way interaction effect between tactile exposure and level of task difficulty on pulse: Under the condition of tactile exposure, pulse will be higher when task is difficult.
H12. There will be a two-way interaction effect between tactile exposure and level of task difficulty on presence in virtual reality: Under the condition of tactile exposure, presence will be higher when task is difficult.
H13: The average difference in SUDs between tactile exposure Yes/No will be mediated by average difference in presence.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The participants will be randomized to one of four factorial conditions: 1) Tactile-augmented VR exposure with low difficulty (wide plank), 2) Tactile-augmented VR exposure with high difficulty (narrow plank), 3) VR-only exposure with low difficulty, 4) VR-only exposure with high difficulty. Participants in each condition will undergo five repeats of an exposure task involving walking out from a skyscraper on a virtual plank (with or without a corresponding physical plank), either narrow or wide. After each repeat, participants provide perceived discomfort and presence ratings using 0-100 scales. Participants wear a pulse band continuously. Immediately after the exposure tasks, participants rate overall sense of control, user-friendliness of the VR application, and cybersickness. At screening, and one week after the experiment, participants provide self-rated fear of heights using online questionnaires.

q9.value: A list of random allocations (1:1:1:1 in block varying from 8 to 12) will be created using a true-randomness generator (randomizer.org), integrated and concealed into a web application from which the experiment leader can draw a ticket prior to data collection.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via posters at the university and online advertisements. Participants will be invited to visit a study website where they fill out a screening survey and provide informed consent. Experimenters will assess participants’ eligibility and those who met criteria and provided the informed consent will be invited to an intervention session at the university. Participants will be rewarded with cinema tickets and a free self-help book for fear of heights. Participants must be at least 18 years old, understand Swedish and score above 25 points (out of 120 possible) on Acrophobia Questionnaire - Anxiety (AQ; Cohen, 1977). Exclusion criteria are: 1) current phobia treatment, 2) lack of stereoscopic vision and balance problems, 3) predisposition to simulator sickness.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants.

q14.value: With N=25*4 we have 83% power to detect a main effect of d larger than 0.6 and an interaction effect of d larger than 1.2. If the effect (of tactile augmentation) is smaller than 0.6, it is questionable clinically whether it is worthy of inclusion in this case.

question.value:
(0) Time (repetition 1-5)
(1) Tactile augmentation by addition of physical plank mapped to virtual plank
(2) Difficulty: Width of virtual (and possibly mapped physical) plank

Fear of heights: Acrophobia Questionnaire – Anxiety (AQ) (Cohen, 1977); measured pre- and post-session.

Discomfort: Max SUDs per trial measured on the scale from 0 to 100; measured during exposition. 

Pulse: Max heart rate per trial measured with pulse band; measured during exposition.

Pulse: Average heart rate per trial measured with pulse band; measured during exposition.

Self-Rated Presence: measured on the scale from 0 to 100; measured before, during, and right after exposition.

In-session outcome will be analyzed using mixed effects models, with binary factor variables and a numeric time variable. We will use lme4 and lmertest for mixed effects modeling, that use Satterthwaite's degrees of freedom method to calculate standard errors (and thereby p values). Mediation analyses will be done in lavaan with bootstrapped standard errors. Pre-post session effect on fear of heights will be analyzed using generalized estimating equations.

q23.value: By design, there will be no missing data unless due to technical or administration errors, which will be treated as missing completely at random and handled using observation-based omission

q25.value:
References

Cohen, D. C. (1977). Comparison of self-report and overt-behavioral procedures for assessing acrophobia. Behavior Therapy, 8(1), 17–23. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0005-7894(77)80116-0

(1) Tactile augmentation by addition of physical plank mapped to virtual plank
(2) Difficulty: Width of virtual (and possibly mapped physical) plank

Fear of heights: Acrophobia Questionnaire – Anxiety (AQ) (Cohen, 1977); measured pre- and post-session.

registration_responses.q19.question: In-session outcome will be analyzed using mixed effects models, with binary factor variables and a numeric time variable. We will use lme4 and lmertest for mixed effects modeling, that use Satterthwaite's degrees of freedom method to calculate standard errors (and thereby p values). Mediation analyses will be done in lavaan with bootstrapped standard errors. Pre-post session effect on fear of heights will be analyzed using generalized estimating equations.

q1.value: Judgments of learning as retrieval practice

q3.value: It is sometimes necessary to predict how one will perform on a future memory task. For example, when studying for an upcoming exam, a student may predict their future performance to adjust their current study strategies. Such predictions are called judgments of learning (JOLs) and have been studied in various contexts (Rhodes, 2015). Often, JOLs reveal overconfidence among participants (Rhodes, 2015). However, delayed JOLs—those made some time after the learning phase of the experiment—are more predictive of future memory performance than immediate JOLs (Dunlosky & Nelson, 1994; Rhodes & Tauber, 2011). Immediate JOLs can be as accurate as delayed JOLs if the item to be remember is displaced from working memory by some secondary task (Bui et al., 2018). Judgments of learning, then, may rely on an underlying attempt to retrieve the item from long-term storage. The purpose of the current study is to test whether JOLs outperform additional study trials or retrieval practice trials on memory performance.

q4.value: We expect participants who engage in cue-only JOLs to have significantly higher recall scores than those who make JOLs given the cue–stimulus pair and those who engage in a re-study trial.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to a condition and complete the entire study via Qualtrics. The researchers will be blind to individual participants' conditions.

question.value: The study will conform to a single factor, 4-group (study method: cue–stimulus JOL, cue-only JOL, retrieval practice, re-study) between-participants design. Upon arrival, all participants will be given and instructed to fill out an informed consent form. Participants will complete the study on a computer using Qualtrics. The Qualtrics application will randomly assign participants to one of the four study groups. All groups receive a set of 15 cue and stimulus word pairs and instructed to learn and memorize the word pairs (study phase). Then they will complete a 5–10-minute unrelated filler task. After the filler task, participants in the cue–stimulus JOL group will review each of the 15 cues and stimuli one at a time and will make a JOL (rating of how sure they are that will recall the stimulus word later). The cue-only JOL group will review only the list of the cues they studied will make JOLs without the stimulus words present. The retrieval practice group will complete the Memorization Test. The restudy group will be instructed to re-study the cues and stimuli, and they will repeat the study phase of the experiment. After this task, participants will complete another 5–10-minute unrelated filler task. Then, all participants will complete the Memorization Test. Finally, all participants will complete the demographics and memory questionnaire. All participants will read the debriefing statement on Qualtrics and will be dismissed.

q9.value: Qualtrics will randomly assign participants to one of the four conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants in this study will be up to 120 college students taking undergraduate psychology classes at a small midwestern university in the spring of 2020. Participants can possibly receive credit for participating in this study; however, their instructors will provide alternatives. Participants will be obtained through the Psychology Department Research Pool sign-up form in Canvas.

We will exclude participants who do not complete the experimental manipulation (i.e., if any of the questions from the retrieval practice or JOL trials are not answered).

q13.value: We are planning to recruit up to 120 participants in the study.

q14.value: The primary constraint affecting data collection is size of the participant pool. G*Power indicates power = .80 with 120 participants to detect effect medium effects (.30) at alpha = .05.

question.value: We will manipulate participants' study strategy. Participants will be assigned to (1) re-study the same list of word-pairs, (2) cue-stimulus JOL, (3) cue-only JOL, and (4) practice retrieving the word-pairs in a cued recognition format.
Our primary dependent variable of interest is participants' memory scores for the studied word-pairs.

The primary model of interest is a one-way ANOVA with study group as the independent variable and performance on the final memory test as the dependent variable.

A secondary model of interest is a linear model with study group as the independent variable, performance on the study trial as a covariate, and performance on the final memory test as the independent variable.

Follow-up analyses might include confidence-accuracy calibrations in the JOL conditions.

registration_responses.q3: It is sometimes necessary to predict how one will perform on a future memory task. For example, when studying for an upcoming exam, a student may predict their future performance to adjust their current study strategies. Such predictions are called judgments of learning (JOLs) and have been studied in various contexts (Rhodes, 2015). Often, JOLs reveal overconfidence among participants (Rhodes, 2015). However, delayed JOLs—those made some time after the learning phase of the experiment—are more predictive of future memory performance than immediate JOLs (Dunlosky & Nelson, 1994; Rhodes & Tauber, 2011). Immediate JOLs can be as accurate as delayed JOLs if the item to be remember is displaced from working memory by some secondary task (Bui et al., 2018). Judgments of learning, then, may rely on an underlying attempt to retrieve the item from long-term storage. The purpose of the current study is to test whether JOLs outperform additional study trials or retrieval practice trials on memory performance.

q1.value: Do competing interpretations of the Women's March as a success or failure impact

q3.value:
This study examines the impact of exposure to representations of successful and failed social movements on individuals’ willingness to engage in collective action and their efficacy beliefs for social change. 

Research on social movements suggests that activists tell stories about past collective action to attract recruits and drive engagement (Zamponi, 2013). Qualitative and historical evidence from this literature shows that collective memories of successful actions may be particularly galvanizing (Armstrong & Crage, 2006), whereas memories of failed actions may have a suppressing effect on the strength and sustainability of social movements (Voss, 1998).  Can representations of past collective action as successful (vs. failed) drive individual collective action intentions? If so, what are the psychological mechanisms underlying this influence? We expect that participation in successful collective actions can lead to increased collective efficacy beliefs (Tausch & Becker, 2013), a key psychological predictor of collective action (e.g. Van Zomeren, Postmes &Spears, 2008).

q4.value:
Primary Hypotheses: 

1.	Compared to the failure condition, exposure to the success condition will be associated with greater efficacy beliefs (H1a) and greater intentions to participate in future collective action (H1b). 
2.	The impact of the success condition (vs. failure condition) on collective action intentions will be mediated by collective efficacy (H2). 

Secondary Hypotheses:

1.	Compared to the failure condition, exposure to the success condition will be associated with greater feelings of hope for change (H3). 
2.	The impact of the success condition (vs. failure condition) on collective action intentions will be mediated by feelings of hope for change (H4).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
An experimental study will examine the effects of representations of the inaugural Women’s March of 2017 as either a success or failure on outcomes related to collective action in the present. The population of interest are women based in the U.S. 

Participants, to be recruited through MTurk, will be randomly assigned to one of two conditions: success condition (participants will read an article framing the Women’s March as a success) versus failure condition (participants will read an article framing the Women’s March as a failure). 

First, participants will complete the experimental tasks (i.e., read the assigned article). Then they will answer the attention checks, followed by outcome measures (dependent variables and mediators), and demographic questions.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Data collection procedures: 

We will advertise our study on Amazon MTurk. Only adult self-identifying women based in the U.S. will be able to see the advertisement. If people choose to participate, they can access the study through link on the advertisement. Our population of interest are non-conservative women based in the U.S.

q13.value: Our total anticipated sample size is 300 participants.

q14.value: A priori power analyses revealed that a total sample of 300 individuals (150 in each condition) would be sufficient to detect a significant one-tailed t-test with effect size .30 with .80 power.

question.value:
Dependent variable: Collective action will be measured as an intention and as a behavior.

•	The intention measure consists of 9 items asking participants to rate the likelihood of them performing given task in the future (e.g. attending a march). 
•	The behavioral component will be captured by two items giving participants the option to either end the study early or to click on links to learn more about ways they can get involved. 

Mediators: 
•	Political efficacy: Eight items will measure the extent to which people believe that social change is possible through collective action. 
•	Identity consolidation efficacy: Four items will measure the extent to which people believe that building a movement and mobilizing is possible through collective action.
•	Hope: Hope for making progress towards gender equality will be measured with three items.

The intended list of measured variables is collective action intentions, collective action intentions for Women's march-specific activities, political efficacy, identity consolidation efficacy hope and the two separate behavioral measures.  For the first 4 in this list,  we will conduct confirmatory factor analyses to confirm that this a priori factor breakdown fits the data sufficiently. We will then form manifest indicators efficacy, emotion and intentions variables by taking the average of all items. The two behavioral variables will be treated as binary.

We will use t-tests to test for main effects of condition (H1a, H1b) and structural equation models (with manifest variables) to test mediational pathways (H2). We will use the same procedure to test our secondary hypotheses. 

As an exploratory analysis, we will examine whether the effects are moderated by whether participants participated in the one of the Women's March protests.

q22.value:
We will recruit 375 participants. We expect between 10-25% of the collected data to be un-useable due to data quality issues or exclusions. To narrow our sample to the target population we will exclude (1) participants who are not based in the US; (2) those who do not self-identify as a woman; (3) those who self-identify as conservatives and (4); those who do not believe gender inequality is a problem in the U.S.; (5) those who failed an attention check; (6) those who fail to complete a majority of items; and (7) those who completed the survey in under 3 minutes. 

We will collect data till we reach 300 participants that meet the eligible criteria for inclusion in
data analysis listed above.

registration_responses.q1: Do competing interpretations of the Women's March as a success or failure impact
registration_responses.q3:
This study examines the impact of exposure to representations of successful and failed social movements on individuals’ willingness to engage in collective action and their efficacy beliefs for social change. 

Research on social movements suggests that activists tell stories about past collective action to attract recruits and drive engagement (Zamponi, 2013). Qualitative and historical evidence from this literature shows that collective memories of successful actions may be particularly galvanizing (Armstrong & Crage, 2006), whereas memories of failed actions may have a suppressing effect on the strength and sustainability of social movements (Voss, 1998).  Can representations of past collective action as successful (vs. failed) drive individual collective action intentions? If so, what are the psychological mechanisms underlying this influence? We expect that participation in successful collective actions can lead to increased collective efficacy beliefs (Tausch & Becker, 2013), a key psychological predictor of collective action (e.g. Van Zomeren, Postmes &Spears, 2008).
registration_responses.q4:
Primary Hypotheses: 

1.	Compared to the failure condition, exposure to the success condition will be associated with greater efficacy beliefs (H1a) and greater intentions to participate in future collective action (H1b). 
2.	The impact of the success condition (vs. failure condition) on collective action intentions will be mediated by collective efficacy (H2). 

Secondary Hypotheses:

1.	Compared to the failure condition, exposure to the success condition will be associated with greater feelings of hope for change (H3). 
2.	The impact of the success condition (vs. failure condition) on collective action intentions will be mediated by feelings of hope for change (H4).

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: In Study 1, 161 participants were included in analyses. This sample size was based on our power calculations. This was entered into G*Power for an a priori power analysis, which estimated a total sample size of 128 to reach a power of .80 at p = .05. Based on previous studies conducted by our lab, which similarly involve deception and a complicated procedure, we estimate up to 15% of participants who either are suspicious, or encounter computer malfunctions or procedural errors. Therefore, we set a target sample size of 148.

analyses.value:
A two-way ANOVA will be conducted to determine whether there are differences in tokens allocated by the emotion and target identity conditions. 


A linear regression will be also be conducted to examine how the degree of perceived similarity to the confederate predicts tokens given by emotion condition. We will examine similarity to target as a function of both the category of the manipulation and self-reported similarity to the target. In addition, we will also examine gratitude’s viability as a mediator for giving decisions with a path-analytic framework.

outliers.value: Exclusions: Participant data will be excluded from analyses if they: (1) do not identify as a U.S. native (meaning they have spent the majority of their life living in the U.S.), or (2) express suspicion during the debriefing session, or provide nonsensical data.

dependent.value: Participants will complete the give-some-game as a measure of economic cooperation. In this task, participants are asked the number of tokens (0-4) they want to allocate to their partner (either an ingroup or outgroup confederate). They also are given instructions that that each token is worth 1 lottery entry to themselves, and 2 lottery entries to their partner.

conditions.value: The study will utilize a 3 (Emotion condition: gratitude, amusement, neutral) X 2 (Target identity: in-group, out-group) between-subjects design.

hypothesis.value:
Can gratitude foster intergroup cooperation? The goal of this experiment is to examine the potential use of gratitude to attenuate intergroup bias in cooperative tasks. Previous literature has demonstrated an ingroup favoritism bias during economic games, where individuals are more likely to cooperate with those perceived as similar to oneself (e.g., Baillet, Wu, & De Dreu, 2014). As gratitude is linked to prosociality during cooperative tasks (DeSteno et al., 2010), we are interested in whether this effect extends across group boundaries. 

In Study 1, results indicated that perceived group affiliation of the partner predicted the number of tokens allocated for both the happiness (β = .52, SE= .13, p <.001) and neutral (β = .38, SE= .12, p = .009) conditions. However, this relationship was not observed for the gratitude condition (β = .06, SE= .12, p = .623). For this study (Study 2), we aim to replicate these findings.

attributes.title: Inter-rater reliability and validity of risk ofbias instrument for non-randomized studiesof exposures: a study protocol

q1.value: Inter-rater reliability and validity of risk ofbias instrument for non-randomized studiesof exposures: a study protocol

q2.value: Maya Jeyaraman, Nameer Al-Yousif, Reid Robson, Leslie Copstein, Chakrapani Balijepalli, Kimberly Hofer, Mir S. Fazeli, Mohammed T. Ansari, Andrea Tricco, Rasheda Rabbani, Ahmed Abou-Setta

q3.value: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

registration_responses.q1: Inter-rater reliability and validity of risk ofbias instrument for non-randomized studiesof exposures: a study protocol
registration_responses.q2: Maya Jeyaraman, Nameer Al-Yousif, Reid Robson, Leslie Copstein, Chakrapani Balijepalli, Kimberly Hofer, Mir S. Fazeli, Mohammed T. Ansari, Andrea Tricco, Rasheda Rabbani, Ahmed Abou-Setta
registration_responses.q3: I confirm this study has been granted in-principle acceptance.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: In Study 1, 155 participants were included in analyses. For Study 2, we calculated the sample size using G*Power for an a priori power analysis, which estimated a total sample size of 252 to reach a power of .80 at p = .05. Based on previous studies conducted by our lab, which similarly involve deception and a complicated procedure, we estimate up to 15% of participants who either are suspicious, or encounter computer malfunctions or procedural errors will be removed. Therefore, we set a target sample size of 290.

analyses.value:
A two-way ANOVA using contrast analyses will be conducted to determine whether there are differences in the average number of points taken across rounds, by the emotion and resource status conditions. 

A mixed ANOVA using contrast analyses will be conducted to examine whether there are differences in point extraction by round (12 rounds total), by the emotion and resource status conditions.

outliers.value: Exclusions: Participant data will be excluded from analyses if they: (1) do not identify as a U.S. native (meaning they have spent the majority of their life living in the U.S.), or (2) express suspicion during the debriefing session, or (3) provide nonsensical data.

dependent.value:
Participants will first complete an emotion induction for either gratitude, happiness, or a neutral state via autobiographical recall.

Next, participants will complete a resource dilemma game. In the task, participants are put into groups that start with a common pool of points (each point = 1 lottery entry for a cash prize). During each round, participants choose how many points to extract for themselves, and how much to leave in the common pool. Whatever is left in the common pool at the end of the round is replenished by 10% for the next round. However, the participant is also aware that if the group collectively extract too much of the resource, over time the common pool will diminish and eventually empty. We will manipulate feedback from the “other players” so that participants believe the others are extracting at a rate that either sustains or rapidly depletes the common pool. We are interested in how many points participants extract by round, as well as their average extraction across rounds.

conditions.value: The study will utilize a 3 (Emotion: gratitude, amusement, neutral) X 2 (Resource status: sustained, depleting) between-subjects design.

hypothesis.value:
The goal of this experiment is to examine the potential use of gratitude to encourage cooperation during a resource dilemma task (adapted by Koole et al., 2001). During this task, participants must decide how many units of a desirable resource to take (knowing that overtaking results in resource depletion). Ultimately, this game presents the dilemma between maximizing either self-interest in the present, or collective interest for the future. As gratitude is linked to both prosociality and self-control, we are interested in whether it can promote cooperation during situations when a desirable resource is at risk for depletion.

In Study 1, results indicated a significant Emotion X Resource Status interaction, F(1, 151) = 5.32, p = .02. Simple effects showed that under a neutral state, point taking increased in the depleting condition compared to the sustained condition (p = .03). However, this difference was not observed in the gratitude condition. For this study (Study 2), we aim to replicate these findings, and add a happiness mood condition to ensure our results from Study 1 were specific to gratitude and not general positive affect.

Therefore, we set a target sample size of 290.

Next, participants will complete a resource dilemma game. In the task, participants are put into groups that start with a common pool of points (each point = 1 lottery entry for a cash prize). During each round, participants choose how many points to extract for themselves, and how much to leave in the common pool. Whatever is left in the common pool at the end of the round is replenished by 10% for the next round. However, the participant is also aware that if the group collectively extract too much of the resource, over time the common pool will diminish and eventually empty. We will manipulate feedback from the “other players” so that participants believe the others are extracting at a rate that either sustains or rapidly depletes the common pool. We are interested in how many points participants extract by round, as well as their average extraction across rounds.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
The goal of this experiment is to examine the potential use of gratitude to encourage cooperation during a resource dilemma task (adapted by Koole et al., 2001). During this task, participants must decide how many units of a desirable resource to take (knowing that overtaking results in resource depletion). Ultimately, this game presents the dilemma between maximizing either self-interest in the present, or collective interest for the future. As gratitude is linked to both prosociality and self-control, we are interested in whether it can promote cooperation during situations when a desirable resource is at risk for depletion.

In Study 1, results indicated a significant Emotion X Resource Status interaction, F(1, 151) = 5.32, p = .02. Simple effects showed that under a neutral state, point taking increased in the depleting condition compared to the sustained condition (p = .03). However, this difference was not observed in the gratitude condition. For this study (Study 2), we aim to replicate these findings, and add a happiness mood condition to ensure our results from Study 1 were specific to gratitude and not general positive affect.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Learning from Passive and Active Pretense: The Role of Gesture and Affect

other.value:
Brief rationale for study: Children’s gesture during embodied learning paradigms has not been studied in play contexts. Most learning from play studies involve children passively engaging with others’ pretense, and most research on learning from gesture does not involve play. Therefore, we will compare children’s gesture across different levels of embodiment while engaged in fictional play: fully embodied, partial embodiment, and no embodiment. While there is strong evidence that suggests gesture helps children’s learning (see Beilock & Goldin-Meadow, 2010; Cameron & Xu, 2011; Cook, Mitchell, & Goldin-Meadow, 2008; Cutica, Ianì, & Bucciarelli, 2014; Goldin-Meadow et al., 2012), the effects of children’s gesture in play contexts has not yet been examined. Additionally, the effects that different types of gestures (i.e., full-bodied versus hands only, or deictic gestures versus metaphoric gestures) have on learning during pretense has not yet been demonstrated. We will examine how children’s gesture usage in embodied play contexts impacts their learning of facts during the play scenarios.  

Use of existing data: The existing data have been analyzed for learning outcome differences between the three different embodiment conditions (fully embodied/costume, partially embodied/puppet, and no embodiment/video watching/story listening), but the data have yet to be coded for gesture usage. Research assistants will be coding the videos and are not familiar with the current study design or hypotheses. Additionally, a small subset of the data will be used to train research assistants how to code the videos and to reach coding reliability. This subset used for research assistant training will not be used in the final analysis. 

Blinding: Research assistants who ran the study were unaware of the hypotheses, and research assistants who will code the videos will remain unaware of the hypotheses. 

Randomization: This study uses data from three previously conducted studies (Thompson & Goldstein, 2019; Goldstein, Thompson & Kanumuru, under review). Each study randomly assigned participants by age to predetermined groups. 

Data Collection Procedures: Participants were recruited from a mid-Atlantic suburban area surrounding a major metropolitan city. Participants were recruited through advertisements posted on Facebook, Twitter, and the lab website, through local parent group organizations, and through partnerships with local pre-schools. 

Statistical Inference Criteria: We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVAs and the post-hoc tests art statically significant. We will use Tukey’s HSD tests for multiple comparisons procedures. We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the regression analysis is statistically significant.

sample.value:
The sample sizes listed below indicate participants who we intend to include in the analysis. Participants who did not complete the required amount of the protocol to be included in prior analysis are also indicated below and will not be included in the current study analysis. Additionally, because the present study requires video coding, we will exclude additional participants if the video recording of a session is unusable. For example, if there was a technical camera issue such as an out of focus video or the camera lens was blocked.

Study 1: N = 144 (3 additional children failed to complete the protocol and will not be included). 

Study 2: N = 88 (15 additional children failed to complete the required amount of protocol and will not be included).

Study 3: N = 89 (31 additional participants failed to compete the protocol and will not be included).

analyses.value:
Gesture by condition, hypotheses 1-2:

We will have a between-subjects design with three levels (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied) and a continuous measurement of age (between 3 and 5 years old, by month). The independent predictor variable is ‘embodiment condition’ with 3 levels. The dependent variable is ‘gesture frequency.’ 

Possible R code: 
GestureRegression <- aov(gesturefreq ~ as.factor(embodimentcondition))

Gesture for learning, hypotheses 3-5:  

We will use a between-subjects regression analysis. The independent predictor is ‘gesture frequency’ and the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts.’ 

Possible R code: 
GestureRegression <- lm(learning ~ gesturefreq)

We will use a between-subjects, three-way, factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA) design. The independent predictor variables are ‘gesture level’ ‘gesture type’ and ‘affect’ the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts’. Gesture level has 2 levels (hand, body), gesture type has 5 levels (deictic, iconic, metaphoric, symbolic, and beats) and affect has 3 levels (negative, neutral, positive). The dependent variable is learning. 

Possible R code: 
GestureAffectAnova <- aov(learning ~ as.factor(gesturetype)*as.factor(gesturelevel)*as.factor(affect))

Affect by condition, hypothesis 5:

We will use a between-subjects design with three levels (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied). The dependent variable is ‘affect.’

Possible R code: 
AffectAnova <- aov(affect ~ as.factor(embodimentcondition))

Affect for learning, hypothesis 6:

We will use a between-subjects regression analysis. The independent predictor is ‘affect’ and the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts.’ 

AffectRegression <- lm(learning ~ affect)

outliers.value: Participants who did not complete the protocol in study 1 and 3, due to lack of attention or asking to finish their participation before completing the study were removed from the data, as is typical with developmental samples. Participants in study 2 were included in analysis as long as they completed at least 1 vignette of the 3 vignette protocol. Additionally, because the present study requires video coding, gesture and affect data will be excluded if it is not codable. For example, the child is out of the camera frame during the session, or if there was a technical camera issue such as an out of focus video or the camera lens was blocked.

dependent.value:
Affect is measured in a simple 3 level categorization: negative affect (coded as 0), neutral affect (coded as 1), positive affect (coded as 2). Please see affect coding guide for more detail.   

Frequency of gesture is measured. This was coded in videos as a simple tally of presence of gesture occurrence within each scenario. 

Frequency of gesture level used is measured, which includes the differentiation of presence/absence of body gestures and hand gestures. The frequency of type of gesture used is also measured, which includes the presence/absence of the gestures underlying function (deictic, iconic, metaphoric, symbolic, and beats).

The outcome variable will be the correct or incorrect responses about facts from the pretend play stories the children experience.

conditions.value: There were three conditions that differed by level of embodiment in pretend play scenarios (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied).

hypothesis.value:
Gesture by condition. 
1)	We expect to find that children gesture more in the fully embodied condition than both the partially embodied condition and the no embodiment condition.
2)	 We expect to find that the children gesture more in the partially embodied condition than the no embodiment condition. 

Gesture for learning. We expect amount of and type of gesture to positively affect learning, regardless of condition/level of embodiment of the play. 

3)	If gesture affects learning, then we expect greater learning outcomes will be seen in children who exhibit more gestures, regardless of embodiment condition.
4)	We expect children’s learning outcomes will be better for those who exhibit more full-bodied gestures than hand gestures only. 

Affect by condition. 
5)	We expect that children’s affect will be more positive for the fully embodied condition than the partially embodied and no embodiment conditions. Accordingly, we expect that children’s affect will be more positive for the partially embodied condition than the no embodiment conditions. 

Affect for learning. 
6)	We expect that children’s learning outcomes will be better for the conditions in which they demonstrated more positive affect.

registration_responses.data: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.
registration_responses.name: Learning from Passive and Active Pretense: The Role of Gesture and Affect
registration_responses.other:
Brief rationale for study: Children’s gesture during embodied learning paradigms has not been studied in play contexts. Most learning from play studies involve children passively engaging with others’ pretense, and most research on learning from gesture does not involve play. Therefore, we will compare children’s gesture across different levels of embodiment while engaged in fictional play: fully embodied, partial embodiment, and no embodiment. While there is strong evidence that suggests gesture helps children’s learning (see Beilock & Goldin-Meadow, 2010; Cameron & Xu, 2011; Cook, Mitchell, & Goldin-Meadow, 2008; Cutica, Ianì, & Bucciarelli, 2014; Goldin-Meadow et al., 2012), the effects of children’s gesture in play contexts has not yet been examined. Additionally, the effects that different types of gestures (i.e., full-bodied versus hands only, or deictic gestures versus metaphoric gestures) have on learning during pretense has not yet been demonstrated. Research assistants will be coding the videos and are not familiar with the current study design or hypotheses. Additionally, a small subset of the data will be used to train research assistants how to code the videos and to reach coding reliability. This subset used for research assistant training will not be used in the final analysis. 

Blinding: Research assistants who ran the study were unaware of the hypotheses, and research assistants who will code the videos will remain unaware of the hypotheses. 

Randomization: This study uses data from three previously conducted studies (Thompson & Goldstein, 2019; Goldstein, Thompson & Kanumuru, under review). Each study randomly assigned participants by age to predetermined groups. 

Data Collection Procedures: Participants were recruited from a mid-Atlantic suburban area surrounding a major metropolitan city. Participants were recruited through advertisements posted on Facebook, Twitter, and the lab website, through local parent group organizations, and through partnerships with local pre-schools. 

Statistical Inference Criteria: We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVAs and the post-hoc tests art statically significant. We will use Tukey’s HSD tests for multiple comparisons procedures. We will use the standard p<0.05 criteria for determining if the regression analysis is statistically significant.
registration_responses.sample:
The sample sizes listed below indicate participants who we intend to include in the analysis. Participants who did not complete the required amount of the protocol to be included in prior analysis are also indicated below and will not be included in the current study analysis. Additionally, because the present study requires video coding, we will exclude additional participants if the video recording of a session is unusable. For example, if there was a technical camera issue such as an out of focus video or the camera lens was blocked.

Study 1: N = 144 (3 additional children failed to complete the protocol and will not be included). 

Study 2: N = 88 (15 additional children failed to complete the required amount of protocol and will not be included).

Study 3: N = 89 (31 additional participants failed to compete the protocol and will not be included).
registration_responses.analyses:
Gesture by condition, hypotheses 1-2:

We will have a between-subjects design with three levels (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied) and a continuous measurement of age (between 3 and 5 years old, by month). The independent predictor variable is ‘embodiment condition’ with 3 levels. The dependent variable is ‘gesture frequency.’ 

Possible R code: 
GestureRegression <- aov(gesturefreq ~ as.factor(embodimentcondition))

Gesture for learning, hypotheses 3-5:  

We will use a between-subjects regression analysis. The independent predictor is ‘gesture frequency’ and the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts.’ 

Possible R code: 
GestureRegression <- lm(learning ~ gesturefreq)

We will use a between-subjects, three-way, factorial analysis of variance (ANOVA) design. The independent predictor variables are ‘gesture level’ ‘gesture type’ and ‘affect’ the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts’. Gesture level has 2 levels (hand, body), gesture type has 5 levels (deictic, iconic, metaphoric, symbolic, and beats) and affect has 3 levels (negative, neutral, positive). The dependent variable is learning. 

Possible R code: 
GestureAffectAnova <- aov(learning ~ as.factor(gesturetype)*as.factor(gesturelevel)*as.factor(affect))

Affect by condition, hypothesis 5:

We will use a between-subjects design with three levels (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied). The dependent variable is ‘affect.’

Possible R code: 
AffectAnova <- aov(affect ~ as.factor(embodimentcondition))

Affect for learning, hypothesis 6:

We will use a between-subjects regression analysis. The independent predictor is ‘affect’ and the dependent variable is ‘learning of the facts.’ 

AffectRegression <- lm(learning ~ affect)
registration_responses.outliers: Participants who did not complete the protocol in study 1 and 3, due to lack of attention or asking to finish their participation before completing the study were removed from the data, as is typical with developmental samples. Participants in study 2 were included in analysis as long as they completed at least 1 vignette of the 3 vignette protocol. Additionally, because the present study requires video coding, gesture and affect data will be excluded if it is not codable. For example, the child is out of the camera frame during the session, or if there was a technical camera issue such as an out of focus video or the camera lens was blocked.
registration_responses.dependent:
Affect is measured in a simple 3 level categorization: negative affect (coded as 0), neutral affect (coded as 1), positive affect (coded as 2). Please see affect coding guide for more detail.   

Frequency of gesture is measured. This was coded in videos as a simple tally of presence of gesture occurrence within each scenario. 

Frequency of gesture level used is measured, which includes the differentiation of presence/absence of body gestures and hand gestures. The frequency of type of gesture used is also measured, which includes the presence/absence of the gestures underlying function (deictic, iconic, metaphoric, symbolic, and beats).

The outcome variable will be the correct or incorrect responses about facts from the pretend play stories the children experience.
registration_responses.conditions: There were three conditions that differed by level of embodiment in pretend play scenarios (no embodiment, partially embodied, fully embodied).
registration_responses.hypothesis:
Gesture by condition. 
1)	We expect to find that children gesture more in the fully embodied condition than both the partially embodied condition and the no embodiment condition.
2)	 We expect to find that the children gesture more in the partially embodied condition than the no embodiment condition. 

Gesture for learning. We expect amount of and type of gesture to positively affect learning, regardless of condition/level of embodiment of the play. 

3)	If gesture affects learning, then we expect greater learning outcomes will be seen in children who exhibit more gestures, regardless of embodiment condition.
4)	We expect children’s learning outcomes will be better for those who exhibit more full-bodied gestures than hand gestures only. 

Affect by condition. 
5)	We expect that children’s affect will be more positive for the fully embodied condition than the partially embodied and no embodiment conditions. Accordingly, we expect that children’s affect will be more positive for the partially embodied condition than the no embodiment conditions. 

Affect for learning. 
6)	We expect that children’s learning outcomes will be better for the conditions in which they demonstrated more positive affect.

q2.value: Laura Vianna, Sapna Cheryan, Stereotypes Identity and Belonging Lab, Lu Song
